title: Counting Happy Ice Cream Wrapper Strings
problem_statement:
Counting Happy Ice Cream Wrapper Strings

Swaraj and his friends have gone on a drive, happily listening to music and chatting with each other. Now they have stopped by an ice cream parlour and want to eat ice cream. Each ice cream wrapper has a string written on it, consisting of uppercase English letters.

Their mood (happy or sad) changes based on the letters they read on the wrapper:

  • H: Always makes them happy.
  • S, D: Always makes them sad.
  • Vowels (A, E, I, O, U): Flip their current mood (happy becomes sad; and vice versa).
  • Other consonants: Do not change their mood.

Initially, they are happy. Given an integer N, representing the length of the string on the wrapper, count how many strings of length N will make them happy after reading the entire string. Print the answer modulo 109 + 7.

Input Format

A single integer N, representing the length of the string.

Output Format

A single integer, the number of strings that will make them happy, modulo 109 + 7.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ N ≤ 105

Examples

Input:
1
Output:
19

Strings that will make them happy are:

B, C, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N, P, Q, R, T, V, W, X, Y, Z

The following letters should not be counted:

  • A, E, I, O, U - These are vowels, and they flip their mood. Since they start happy, reading a vowel makes them sad.
  • S, D - These letters always make them sad.

Therefore, there are 19 letters that will make them happy after reading the string.

title: Drowning Ship
problem_statement:
There is a cargo ship that contains an unlimited amount of cargo. The ship is ready to sail, and you have a list of N non-negative integers that denote the water level in the sea at i-th points.

A wave is defined as continuously increasing or decreasing sequence of water levels. For each wave, you need to calculate the cargo that falls into the sea. The cargo that falls into the sea is determined by the smallest height of the wave and the width (length) of the wave.

For example, given A = [1, 2, 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 8, 9, 7], it has 6 waves:

  • [1, 2, 6]: Smallest height = 1, Width = 3 → Cargo = 1 * 3 = 3
  • [6, 4, 2]: Smallest height = 2, Width = 3 → Cargo = 2 * 3 = 6
  • [2, 3]: Smallest height = 2, Width = 2 → Cargo = 2 * 2 = 4
  • [3, 1]: Smallest height = 1, Width = 2 → Cargo = 1 * 2 = 2
  • [1, 8, 9]: Smallest height = 1, Width = 3 → Cargo = 1 * 3 = 3
  • [9, 7]: Smallest height = 7, Width = 2 → Cargo = 7 * 2 = 14

The total amount of cargo that falls into the sea is: 3 + 6 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 14 = 32.

Input Format

The first line contains an integer N, representing the number of water level points.

The second line contains N space-separated integers, representing the water levels at different points.

Output Format

A single integer, the total amount of cargo that falls into the sea.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ N ≤ 105
  • 1 ≤ A[i] ≤ 103

Examples

Input:
10
1 2 6 4 2 3 1 8 9 7
Output:
32

In the given example, the waves are:

  • [1, 2, 6]: Smallest height = 1, Width = 3 → Cargo = 1 * 3 = 3
  • [6, 4, 2]: Smallest height = 2, Width = 3 → Cargo = 2 * 3 = 6
  • [2, 3]: Smallest height = 2, Width = 2 → Cargo = 2 * 2 = 4
  • [3, 1]: Smallest height = 1, Width = 2 → Cargo = 1 * 2 = 2
  • [1, 8, 9]: Smallest height = 1, Width = 3 → Cargo = 1 * 3 = 3
  • [9, 7]: Smallest height = 7, Width = 2 → Cargo = 7 * 2 = 14

The total amount of cargo that falls into the sea is: 3 + 6 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 14 = 32.

title: Minimum Divisor
problem_statement:
Minimum Divisor

You are given an array of integers. Given an integer x, define array b of size n such that b[i] = a[i] + x and b[i] is an integer and as large as possible. Define f(x) as the sum of all elements of b. Determine the smallest positive x such that f(x) ≤ k.

It can be proven that there exists a unique array b given array a and integer x.

Input Format

The first line contains n and k.

The second line contains n elements, the array a.

Output Format

Print the smallest positive x such that f(x) ≤ k.

Constraints

  • 1 ≤ n ≤ 105
  • 1 ≤ k ≤ 109
  • 1 ≤ a[i] ≤ 109

Examples

Input:
3 8
1 5 7
Output:
2

Consider x = 2:

  • Array b = [0, 2, 3]
  • f(x) = 5

It can be shown that selecting x as anything smaller than 2 will result in f(x) > 8.
